columns.text: In this task, **we should answer which bond contains a higher risk.**

The investment in the Treasury bond is less risky and will provide **lower coupons**, but government bonds are sensitive to the interest rate risk.  
Investment in the corporate bond has a higher coupon because of the higher riskiness.

**In this example, we have 30 years of bonds maturity. It is a long-term period. Therefore, the investment in government bonds will have a higher interest risk than corporate bonds**.
We need to determine who's more (interest) risk-prone: U.S. treasury or BB ranked company, both with the same 30 year maturity.

**Ranking** is evaluation of respectable bond-ranking-bodies and represents quality of the bond and company's ability to repay the debt consistently.

For note, BB rank is falls under **low-quality investment**.

**Interest rate risk represents the change in bond value/price with fluctuation of interest rate, as well as changing the payback risk for the lender**.

With that in mind, U.S. Treasury is one of the most reliable choices for bond purchase because, while it can suffer from inflation or external burden, U.S. Treasury can always generate more money (by printing it, taxation, etc.) to pay back the bond, even with interest fluctuation (as it will always have money to adapt).

On the other hand, BB ranked bond already has a decent risk of being paid pack even without interest rate fluctuation. If interest rate is unstable, 30 years is incredibly long run, and even with that the risk increases, let alone with company's shaky financial growth (as defined per BB rank, if it were A for example, company would be financially stable and able to generate bond-repaying/sinking fund).

Therefore, BB rank has greater interest rate risk.
